data.title: Barbara Walters comes under fire for defending Woody Allen on 'The View'
data.meta_description: Barbara Walters came under fire on social media sites Monday after she defended writer/director Woody Allen on charges he molested his daughter.
data.text:
Barbara Walters came under fire on social media sites Monday after she defended writer/director Woody Allen on charges he molested his daughter.

Twitter users are expressing shock that Walters defended Allen, whom she says she knows personally.

Her comments came on the day after Allen's daughter, Dylan, wrote an open letter that was published in the New York Times, renewing the claims she made in 1992 that she was molested by Allen when she was a child.

Allen has denied the claims and was never charged with a crime. He said Sunday that the letter was "untrue and disgraceful."

In the letter, Dylan urged fans of Allen's movies and actors who star in them, not to "turn a blind eye" to her accusations of abuse.

Walters and "The View" co-host Sherri Sheppard got into a heated exchange on the show after Walters said she knows Allen to be "a loving father." Sheppard countered, saying no one knows what happens in another person's home.

Sheppard went on to say that Allen's marriage to his step-daughter, Soon Yi Previn, shows he is attracted to young girls.

Later in the show, Walters also commented on Mary Kay Letourneau, the teacher who had a relationship with a 13-year-old student whom she became pregnant by and later married. Walters said Letourneau's relationship with the then teen-age boy was "weird."

Soon after her comments, Walters' name became a trending topic on Twitter. Here are some of those comments:
